reviewText: A Twist of the Wrist 2 DVDI hesitated to order this DVD based on all of the reviews that commented on the corny acting. Once I watched it, I have to admit the acting wasn't that bad and it did not detract from any of Keith Code's lessons. Some of the basic rules from his book are covered in an interesting way. Code lectures to a group of young riders, going over the basic concepts in a "slow" and elementary manner to show that this isn't rocket science.Usually the survival reactions and problems are introduced with the 2 main characters complaining after a ride on the road or a few laps on the track. Keith or someone else interjects and takes it into the classroom or the narrator begins covering the problem, solution, and theory. One of the problems I had was staying awake throughout the DVD. The English narrator's tone is extremely boring, but the lessons are important.I found the DVD to be far more useful than both of his books, although Twist of the Wrist 2 (the book) is something I'd highly recommend. The lessons are more oriented towards intermediate to experienced riders headed for track days, although as a beginner, I found the cornering lessons to be useful in passing the Basic RiderCourse and getting my endorsement.Overall: 4/5 stars
summary: Supplements the book well, but also good as a standalone. I struggled to stay awake though
Title: N/A

reviewText: My thing is cars rather than motorcycles (rode a motorcycle as a kid), but the "Twist of the Wrist" book was highly recommended by Carroll Smith, who I respect, so I got both the book and this DVD.I think the DVD is very well done, with excellent production quality.  It illustrates well, and often humorously, the struggles riders face in trying to improve, and addresses those struggles with great advice, supported by explanations of why the advice works in terms of basic physics.  I can't see how any non-expert rider wouldn't benefit from this.And I was intrigued to find that Carroll Smith is right.  The basic principles are very much the same for both motorcycles and cars, so watching this DVD helped me as a driver, and it was time well spent.Highly recommended for anyone involved in motor sports, and a great value too.

reviewText: I am new to riding and need as much information as I can get.  This video is a little on the cheesy side, but it does have some good information that anyone can learn from - new or experienced.

reviewText: This is a great video from Keith Code.  Keith has been training riders for decades and has great insight into what it takes to master the control of a motorcycle.  The production quality is good.  Ideally you would use the video and the book in conjunction.  Sometimes, like when describing the line through a corner, it is easier to "see" the line from an illustration than it is from a video of the riders perspective.
summary: A great video from Keith Code

reviewText: This is one of several books on riding motorcycles that should be read by anyone who rides a motorcycle, or just dreams about it. There's a lot in it that is applicable to street riding, and definitely track riding. Putting to use some of techniques have made me a better rider, more confident in my skill and my bike's limits.

reviewText: The best,most important riding video out there (I've watched them all). It will do more to up your skills and make you a better, safer, faster rider than anything else out there. It's professionally done, smart and funny. I cannot recommend this enough. After 20+ years of riding I thought I knew riding, wow did I have a lot to learn. Keith Code's DVD and the book of the same title are brilliant.
